dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wrecked Ford Mustang burns in the middle of the empty bridge. Empty. No other cars, no people in sight.. There is a gaping hole in the windshield on the driver's side. Flames consume the backseat. Smoke spills out the windows. The radio still plays, however: The Band's "I Sh be Released." One of the Mustang's front tires has blown out. Scraps of black rubber litter the accident scene. As the camera pulls in, we see HENRY LETHAM, twenty, sitt in front of the ruined car. His eyes are closed. He looks sick-- pale, skinny, disheveled-- but he has a presence, a magnetism that compels you to look at him. Finally Henry opens his eyes. After a moment he stands an walks away from the burning car, never turning around, heading for the illuminated towers of Manhattan. Somewhere nearby a BABY is HOWLING, though no one is in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuesday The baby's HOWL continues, faintly, in the background. DR. SAM FOSTER, a psychiatrist in his early forties, wake in bed, disoriented, sunlight shining on the disheveled sheets. For several seconds Sam looks about the apartment, confus as if he's never seen the place before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam parks his old, battered Volvo in front of the Chinese noodle shop. He checks his watch and curses under his bre Sam's hair is beginning to gray, but he's still built lik college tennis player. He smiles readily but there is a brooding quality about him, in his dark eyes, that sugges he has seen things most of us have not

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bells are tolling. Sam dashes through the campus gate Under his tweed blazer he wears a frayed navy-blue cable- sweater. As he rounds a corner he checks his watch, and before he looks up collides with LILA CULPEPPER, knocking her styro cup of coffee to the sidewalk With her stylish haircut and clothing, Lila looks more li young editor of a fashion magazine than a graduate studen Only the thick philosophy textbooks she carries and her r ink stained fingers give her away. She shoves him.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Watch where you're going, old man.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Jesus, kids these days... He kisses her on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: I don't have time to stand here flirting with you. I've got to give a test to Grunbaum's undergrads. Sam stoops to pick up the empty cup, stands straight, crumples the cup, tosses it into a nearby garbage can.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Thank God none of the TAs looked like you when I was a student. I would've flunked every test.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: (unimpressed) Oh, that's sweet. Can I tell you something? She sidles up next to him and fixes the collar of his jac

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: You owe me a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam hurries inside the sleek, angular, glass-and-steel building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam gets out of the elevator and waves to a RECEPTIONIST sitting behind a desk. A sign on the wall behind her read

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hey, Toni.

dialogues.speaker: TONT
dialogues.text: Hey, Sam. Henry Letham's waiting in Beth's office.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Thanks. He walks down the hallway and opens the last door on the left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry, wearing paint-spattered army pants and a black lon sleeve tee-shirt, stands at the window of the bookshelf-l office, looking out at the sky. He stares at Sam when Sam enters the room. Sam smiles and nods.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Henry?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Where's Dr. Levy?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Dr. Levy had an appendectomy, she'll be gone a few weeks. I'm Dr. Foster, I'm covering for her. Sam offers his hand and Henry examines it for a moment be shaking. Sam goes behind the desk to sit and gestures for Henry to sit inn one of the facing chairs. Sam pulls a manila folder from his suitcase. Henry sits o the edge of a facing chair. He looks ready to bolt at any second. Henry holds a piece of string which he coils tightly aro his index finger, then uncoils, then coils again.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: So you're the substitute shrink? Sam smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I guess you could call me that. Does it make you uncomfortable that I'm filling in for Dr. Levy? Henry thinks about it, coiling the string tightly.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Is she your girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No. We were classmates, actually. So listen, I read your file--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Oh, really? May I read your file?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Fair enough. How about you ask me a question for every question I ask you?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: How about we don't play stupid games. Sam smiles and leans back in his chair. Far from being deterred by Henry's attitude, he's intrigued. He likes challenges.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Okay. Tell me why you're here.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You read the file. You ought to know.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You torched your car. Why?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What do you mean, you don't know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Were you drinking?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I opened my eyes and I was sitting in the car and it was on fire. Henry is quiet for a moment, remembering.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Do you often set fires?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No. I'm not a pyromaniac or anything. It's not like I burned flies when I was a kid. (beat) Maybe a couple times I did. Is that bad?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: For the flies it is.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I remember them trying to crawl when they were on fire. Henry is silent for a moment. He coils the string so tigh around his finger that the tip of his finger turns bright red.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe Hell is the place where all the bad things you've done come back to get you. Another pause. Sam points at Henry's finger.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You're cutting off the circulation.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I never meant to hurt anyone.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You were a kid. Kids are cruel.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about the flies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Abruptly, Henry stands, knocking over his chair in the process. He bends down to pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Sorry. I better go.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Are you sure? I feel like we're just getting started.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No, no, I better-- Henry looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll have hail this afternoon. Sam watches him leave and then stares out the window. The is bright blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky is still blue on this beautiful autumn afternoon. and Lila, on rollerblades, slowly roll down the promenade overlooking the Hudson River. Lila holds Sam's hand, steadying him. Lila is obviously skilled; Sam is obviously a beginner. H wears a helmet, kneepads, and elbow pads over his long-sl tee-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Don't lean forward too much.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Try to relax. You're too tense. Try to get the rhythm. You want it to feel natural.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I have wheels strapped to my feet There's nothing natural about it. Two kids on rollerblades whiz by the couple. Sam, trying get out of the way, nearly falls.  One of the kids begins skating backwards. He nudges his friend and imitates Sam's spastic motions. Both of them l and zoom away.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ha ha, you little bastards.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: We don't have to do this, you know. It's supposed to be fun.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I'm having fun. He lets go of Lila's hand and tries to skate in the manne Eric Heiden, pumping his legs with one hand behind his ba going faster and faster.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Sam... Sam, now out of control, begins speeding downhill.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: How do I stop? HOW DO I STOP? Ahead of him, the path forks left and right. He won't be to make the turn at this speed. At the last second, Sam grabs onto a lamppost. He spins around the post and flops into a bush.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: (catching up) Sam? Sam? Sam lies on the ground, catching his breath. He's covered with leaves and dirt. LILA (CONTвЂ™D) You okay? Lila crouches beside him and begins checking him for inju with the practiced skill of a nurse.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I'm fine, I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: That was impressive. She lies down next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm not ready for this. I'm not so coordinated.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: That's okay. You're a sexy klutz. They kiss. Lila pulls herself closer, her hands on Sam's wrists. Abruptly, Sam pulls his long sleeves down farther if to hide something on his wrists. Lila releases him. For a moment both of them are quiet.

dialogues.speaker: LILA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don't have to do that. You don't have to hide from me. Sam doesn't look at her.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I'm not hiding.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Sam. Sam raises his head.

dialogues.speaker: LILA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't hide. She kisses him. In the middle of the kiss a loud CRACK startles both of them.

dialogues.speaker: LILA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What was that? For a few seconds nothing happens. And then another CRACK and then another, coming rapid fire now, grape-size chunk ice falling from the sky and shattering on the paved walkways.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the road through the driver's eyes. We're somewher Brooklyn, driving fast through a string of green lights. Everything is very, very quiet. We turn to the right. A GREEN-EYED WOMAN (20) sits in th passenger seat. She says something, but we can't hear a w She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry opens his eyes. He sits in a car that shudders and rattles its way through the underground. On his lap is a on the artist Tristan RГ©veur. He pulls a cigarette from a pack and lights it. Next to Henry sleeps a long-haired TEENAGE BOY wearing a Walkman: from the headphones we hear "I Shall be Released Various subway riders glare at Henry and wave away the sm obviously annoyed that he's polluting their airspace. A YOUNG WOMAN who wears her blonde hair in dreadlocks sit across the car, watching Henry.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: You go to Columbia, right? We were both in Psych 221. Professor Matthewson? (pointing at his book) You did your oral presentation on psychosis and Tristan RГ©veur right? Henry stares at her as if she's speaking an alien languag BUSINESSMAN standing between them, holding onto the metal pole, wearing a gray suit and carrying an attache case, shakes his head at Henry.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: No smoking on the train.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: (pointing) Look at the sign, fella. No smoking on the train. Henry looks at the sign.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Capeesh? Put it out.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Capeesh? Are you in the Mafia? The businessman leans closer, until his face is inches fr Henry's.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: Put out the fucking cigarette. Henry slowly rolls his shirtsleeve back from his forearm. skin is mottled with fresh burns. He draws on his cigarette until its point is red-hot, the stabs it out on the skin of his wrist. He does not flinch The businessman reels backward. The dreadlocked Columbia student's mouth drops open. The people sitting next to He stand and move away. Henry offers the cigarette butt to the businessman, who w his hand at it and moves away, muttering:

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ought to be locked up.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I am. When the train pulls into the next station, the businessm and the Columbia caucastafarian hastily depart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bookshelves overflowing with books dominate the space. Th one luxurious feature is a working fireplace where a well built little fire now burns. Lila's curled up in bed, highlighting lines in Dante's Purgatorio. Sam, lying beside her, speaks on the PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hey, Beth, this is Sam. Hope you're feeling better. I met with your patient Henry Letham today, thought maybe we could compare notes. Anyway, give me a call.  11. He hangs up and stares into the fire, his hands folded ov his chest.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Lila) You don't think it's a little odd, predicting a hailstorm like that?

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: (not really paying attention) So he watches the Weather Channel.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I looked in the newspaper. There was nothing about any hail today.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Maybe he's a shaman and he did a little hail dance.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Okay, forget it.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: (finally looking up) How's Beth Levy?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I don't know. She hasn't returned any of my calls.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Hm.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What does "hm" mean?

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: She always kind of liked you didn't she? Sam jabs Lila in the ribs with his finger.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What are you, jealous? Beth's one of my oldest friends.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: She's your oldest friend, that's supposed to make me unjealous?  12.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Unjealous?

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: She's in love. It's obvious to everyone but you. And every day you wear that sweater she made you-- She points at the blue sweater, lying folded on top of th dresser.

dialogues.speaker: LILA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --and all I can think is, Damn, I can't even knit.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: She saved my life, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You're the only one for me, all right? I knew I would find you. And I did.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: (kissing him on the lips) It took you long enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wednesday Sam sits behind Beth's desk and Henry sits facing him.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Have you considered a career in meteorology? Henry says nothing, only stares at the chewed-down stubs his fingernails.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT' D)
dialogues.text: The weatherman said something about the hail?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I can't listen to the weatherman anymore. I don't understand a word he says.  13.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You don't understand the weatherman?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Sure. He says rain, I bring an umbrella. Henry stares at Sam for a moment, trying to gauge the psychiatrist. He seems to come to a decision.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don't know what's real anymore.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Go on. (off Henry's non-response) Give me a chance, Henry. I'm good at what I do.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: The voices never stop.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Voices?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: In my head. They never stop.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Why were you so reluctant to tell me that?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don't want to fit into your grid. I don't want you saying, "Okay, paranoid schizophrenic. Two hundred milligrams of Risperdol should do the trick."

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You don't want me making assumptions about you, right? Henry nods.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But aren't you making assumptions about me? You think I want to fit you into a grid? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM(cont 'd) I don't make grids. I want to know the particulars about Henry Letham. You hear voices. All right, that's important information. What are the voices saying? Henry shakes his head and looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think it might be helpful if you start writing it down.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Writing what down?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What the voices are saying. write down the exact words when you hear them. Okay? Henry? Henry hasn't been listening.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Write down what the voices are saying. Henry grabs a pen and a pad of paper from the desk and be writing.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're talking to you now? Henry continues writing furiously. When he finishes he st at his own jagged cursive

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I see? Henry hands the pad over. Sam studies it, straining to re the handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reading) "Write down what the voices are saying... They're talking to you now?" (looking at Henry) That wasn't a hallucination, that was me talking.  15.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You come inside my head, Doctor, and show me how to tell the difference.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (continuing to read) "Stay, Henry, stay. Stay. Stay. Stay." (looking at Henry) You're hearing this voice now? Henry nods, rubbing his palm over his scarred forearm.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you recognize the voice?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You just said you did.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's a woman. I know her, but I don't know who she is.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I don't understand. Henry says nothing, only scratches his forearm. Sam notic the fresh burn on Henry's arm. He stands, goes around the desk, gently takes Henry's arm and inspects it.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's this from?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I burned myself. Sam looks closer. He notices the old burn scars that constellate Henry's forearms.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (more firmly) What are these scars from?  16. Absently, Henry looks at his forearms.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Cigarettes, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Why do you have cigarette scars on your forearms?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Because I keep burning myself. Sam nods and studies Henry for a moment. He releases Henr arm and sits on the edge of the desk

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Why do you want to hurt yourself?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I guess it's practice.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Practice for what?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: For Hell. Sam takes a deep breath and exhales.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You think you're going to Hell? Henry nods.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Because of what I did.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What did you do? Henry shakes his head, stares out the window.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whatever it is, we--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I know you're trying to help me, Doctor. And thank you. But it's too late.  17.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Why is it too late? Henry stands and grabs his bookbag off the floor.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Saturday at midnight I'm going to kill myself. He rubs his arms and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need to get ready. He walks out, leaving a stunned Sam alone in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam walks down the corridor of the Mental Health Ward. He knocks on an office door marked: Mobile Crisis Unit. No answer. As he's about to knock again he hears a commotion the end of the hallway. Two strapping PARAMEDICS are wrestling a fiercely agitate heavy-set woman, DAISY, toward one of the rooms. She appe to be homeless, wearing layer upon layer of filthy clothi her hair matted, her skin dirty and bruised. Standing beside the paramedics, DOCTOR SCHLEGEL, a gaunt with a sparse goatee, tries to calm the woman.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL
dialogues.text: Come on, Daisy. We've got your television turned on and everything. Take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL
dialogues.text: Nobody's calling you a Nazi, Daisy. Come on, now. Sam hurries down the corridor toward the disturbance. Dai falls to the floor and the paramedics, unable to force he into the room, try to hold her still as she thrashes in t arms. Dr. Schlegel has prepared a hypodermic and now crouches waiting for an opportunity to stick Daisy.  18.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL
dialogues.text: I know it, Daisy, I know it.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (beginning to sob) You can't treat me this way. I am not a Nazi! I don't deserve this.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL
dialogues.text: Believe it or not, sweetheart, it's for your own good. The paramedics hold her tight and Schlegel sticks the nee in Daisy's arm. DR. SCHLEGEL (CONTвЂ™D) If you'd remember to take your pills, we wouldn't have to go through this every month.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I'm not a Nazi. I'm lovable.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL
dialogues.text: You are.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (already beginning to fade) I'm lovable. The paramedics hoist Daisy to her feet and lead her peacefully into the bedroom. Dr. Schlegel sees Sam for the first time and smiles, a li embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL
dialogues.text: Hey, Sam. The glamorous world of psychiatry, huh? They shake hands and Schlegel leads Sam back toward the Mobile Crisis Unit office.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what brings you to Club Meds?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I wanted to check the protocol on involuntary committal. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM(cont'd) I've got a student threatening to kill himself.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL
dialogues.text: Jesus, tell him to take a number Well, the rules are pretty straightforward. If he says he's gonna hurt himself or someone else, we can take him in. But we can only hold him here for forty-eight hours.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Forty-eight hours? What are we going to do in forty-eight hours? They stop outside the MCU office.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL
dialogues.text: Hold his hand, feed him some pills. (beat) If we catch him in the actual attempt, that's different. He's broken the law. But just based on a threat? Without a court order, we can't keep him for long.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He wants to do it Saturday at midnight. If we take him in now he'll be out by then.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL
dialogues.text: What, he's got an appointment to off himself?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: That's what he told me. Saturday, midnight.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL
dialogues.text: So maybe we should pick him up Friday, hold him through the weekend. (shaking his head) AS you just saw, it's not a real fun process. If there's any way to avoid it, avoid it. What do you have him on?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He won't take any pills. (beat) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM(cont'd) He wants to die, Jeff. I've got three days to convince him not to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is walking home when he stops to watch PIANO MOVERS a work. Using ropes and pulleys, they hoist a Bechstein bab grand toward the open windows of a fourth-floor apartment PIANO MOVER 1 acts as the foreman, issuing commands.

dialogues.speaker: PIANO MOVER 1
dialogues.text: Easy, easy. A small BOY, accompanied by his MOTHER, runs down the str holding a red balloon. He trips and falls and the balloon begins to float away.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (yelling at escaping balloon) Wait! wait! The piano movers hear the boy's cries and see the balloon Piano Mover 1 makes a valiant effort to capture the escap balloon; he runs after it and leaps... but he can't quite reach it. Everyone watches the red balloon drift skyward.

dialogues.speaker: PIANO MOVER 1
dialogues.text: Sorry, kid. It's gone to balloon heaven. Sam smiles and enters his building, where the DOORMAN gre him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila meets Sam at the door and kisses him on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: I didn't think you were going to make it. I need you to make a fire. You're the only Eagle Scout I've ever dated. She leads him into the bedroom.  21.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I never made Eagle Scout. The Troop Master caught me drinking Mad Dog 20/20 in my tent with Lydia Eumanian.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Lydia Eumanian?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: The horniest thirteen-year-old in Northern New Jersey. Lila curls up at the foot of her bed and watches as Sam g a bundle of twigs from beside the fireplace and starts la down the kindling.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Only because I never lived in Northern New Jersey. Sam begins stacking the logs.

dialogues.speaker: LILA, (CONT' D)
dialogues.text: Are you okay, baby? You look a little tense.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: That student. Henry. He told me he was going to kill himself Saturday night.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Kids at Columbia are always talking about killing themselves. It's hip. It's like wearing black.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I don't think it's a front for this one. Saturday at midnight, he says. Just like that. Like it's a date he's made. Sam rolls an old newspaper and inserts it beneath the sta logs.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Why Saturday? Sam strikes a match and lights the fire.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Why does he want to do it on Saturday? What's so special about midnight Saturday? Sam watches the kindling catch.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He left before I could ask. Confident that the fire is in good shape, Sam walks over the bedside table, picks up the phone and dials a number. waits for a moment and then shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (on phone) Beth, it's Sam again. Where are you? You all right? Uh, okay, give me a call when you get this. He hangs up and sits on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm starting to get a little worried about her.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: I'm starting to get a little worried about you, baby. It's a hell of a job, listening to these crazy boys and girls all day.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: At least I get you all night. Lila grabs Sam by the collar and pulls him over to her. T kiss.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't go crazy on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thursday Sam sits behind the desk and Henry sits facing him. Sam h a typed contract.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I want to propose a deal. I've written up a contract. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM(cont 'd) It says you won't do anything to hurt yourself without contacting me first. And here's my card. It has my home phone and cell phone, so you can call me whenever you want. Henry leans forward and takes the contract and business c from Sam. He reads the contract quickly, signs his name, hands it back to Sam. He pockets the card.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Saturday at midnight I die. Consider yourself contacted. Sam, bewildered, looks at the contract for a moment and t sets it aside.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Why Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's my twenty-first birthday.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I think the tradition is to go out and get drunk, not blow your brains out.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Have you heard of Tristan RГ©veur? He was one of the Dada artists. When he was eighteen he told everyone he would live three more years and then go to New York and kill himself. And that's exactly what he did. He came to New York for his twenty-first birthday, saw the sights, and shot himself in the head. Both of them are silent for a while.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What about your parents? Have you considered what this might do to them?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: They don't care.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: How do you know that?  24.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's pretty obvious.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Do they live around here?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No. They're over in Mahlus Gardens.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Mahlus Gardens? Where's that?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's a cemetery in New Jersey. I thought you read my file.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (startled) I did. It didn't mention anything about that.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's a little out of date, then. Henry stands, walks over to the office window and looks o across the campus.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Any other family? Henry shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Friends? (off Henry's silence) Who are you closest to?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What do you mean, closest to?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: If you got into trouble and you needed someone, who would you go to?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I am in trouble. Henry does not say this in a self-pitying way. He is simp stating a fact.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yes, I think you are.  25.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Then you've got your answer. Sam does not understand.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I came to you, Doctor. I guess that means I'm closest to you.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: To me? We met two days ago. Henry inspects his fingernails.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: There was a girl.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (perking up) A girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I barely even talked to her. She was my waitress at this diner I used to go to. On Canal Street. (beat) She'd keep filling my coffee cup. She'd say, "Is everything okay?" I mean, I know waitresses are always asking that, but... this is stupid.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No, it's not stupid. This waitress did you ever get her name?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Athena.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Athena? Really? (beat) All right, that's a start.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No, it's not. She was in my life for a few minutes and now she's gone.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: She's not gone. She's somewhere else.  26.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: There is no somewhere else. If you're not in my life, you don't exist.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (smiling) You think I disappear when you're not watching?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'm always watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're back in the DRIVER'S POV again, speeding along the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. The Brooklyn Bridge looms in distance, Gothic arches majestically lit We look at the green-eyed woman, but she's speaking to someone in the backseat. Her mouth moves but everything i silent. We turn to the road again. The bridge is waiting for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry enters the Zoo beneath the Delacorte Clock, the bro animals playing their instruments, marking the hour. Henry watches a lone silverback GORILLA who sits on a lar rock, staring back at Henry. Henry sits on a park bench, watching an OLD MAN throw bre crumbs to a horde of squawking pigeons. Henry sits in the last row of the bleachers overlooking t seal pool. The front rows are filled with screaming CHILD On an island in the middle of the pool, TRAINERS toss fis the SEALS as rewards for various tricks: clapping their flippers, jumping through hoops, kissing each other balancing balls on their noses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a blurred Henry through the window of a polar bear tank. The BEAR is swimming laps, never pausing.  27. It's an oddly graceful animal, bulky but elegant, flippin each end of the pool to kick off the wall (one wall being window that Henry stands behind).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry seems mesmerized by the bear's endless swim. A well dressed ENGLISHMAN and ENGLISHWOMAN approach and watch th bear perform its laps.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISHMAN
dialogues.text: (to Henry) You suppose he's bored?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I think he's trying to forget where he is. The Englishman nods and they all watch the bear in silenc for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The polar bear glides soundlessly through the water, igno the blurred faces beyond the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere nearby a BABY is howling. Henry looks around bu there is no baby in sight.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISHMAN
dialogues.text: And is it working? Henry looks at the Englishman.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's hard to forget where you are, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISHMAN
dialogues.text: You tell me. Both the man and his wife smile at Henry and walk away. H watches them go. The unseen baby continues to howl.  28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila sits cross-legged in the grass lawn that fronts the Philosophy building, highlighting lines in a textbook. A feet away, Rodin's bronze Le Penseur sits in permanent contemplation.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So what's he thinking? Lila looks up from her book and sees Sam staring at the statue. She smiles and studies the Thinker for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think therefore I am?

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: It's not thinking anything. It's a statue.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You're kind of literal minded, you know that? She grins and tosses aside her book.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: You grade two hundred papers in a week, see how literal minded you get. (beat) You met with that student today? The suicidal one? Sam squats down beside Lila and picks at the grass. He re his BRIEFCASE on the ground beside him.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He came in, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: And? Why does he want to die? Sam stares at Lila for a while and she looks away, fluste

dialogues.speaker: LILA, (CONT' D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, is that a stupid question? Sam shakes his head. He takes Lila's hand.  29.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No. It's the question. I just don't have an answer yet.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: And you... did you... She's obviously uncomfortable, not sure how to proceed. He kisses Lila sees Sam turns Sam walks

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I need to find something he wants to live for.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: How are you going to do that?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He'll tell me. That's why he keeps coming to see me. (checking his watch) I've got a meeting to get to. See you at home. her on the lips, stands, and begins walking away. that he's left his briefcase lying on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Henry! and stares at her. Lila points at the briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: LILA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Forgetting something? back to her, staring at her the whole time.

dialogues.speaker: LILA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What did you just call me?

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: (confused) What?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You just called me Henry.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Baby, I think I know your name by now.  30.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: But you called me Henry. Lila holds up her hands.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Hey, don't shoot.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No, it's just--

dialogues.speaker: LI LA
dialogues.text: I know who you are, Sam. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay. He grabs his briefcase, kisses her again, and walks away. watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friday Henry sits on the sidewalk outside the cafe, playing cat' cradle with a string. He's good, creating intricate patte and undoing them. Sam walks up to him.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hey. You're early.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I skipped glee club today.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oh. (beat) That's a joke, right?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Sam leads Henry inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, dark cafe where STUDENTS and PROFESSORS drink co and eat homemade pastries. Bad art lines the walls.  31. Henry and Sam find seats in a corner of the room, far awa from everyone else. The song playing on the radio ends; the new song is "I Sh be Released." Henry sits up straight when he hears the song. He stares the nearest stereo speaker as if trying to figure somethi out.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I can't escape this song. (looking at Sam) Why did you want to meet here?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: The Hungarian Cafe? Sentimental favorite. When I was an undergrad I worked here. (pointing) I lost my virginity under that table.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (shocked) You what?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I used to lock up every night. So one time I brought my girlfriend here and we had a bottle of wine, and, you know, one thing led to another. It wasn't very comfortable. Henry laughs and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I never had a shrink tell me something like that.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (looking up at the artworks) They still have the same bad art on the walls.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (looking at the art) Tristan RГ©veur used to say that bad art is more tragically beautiful than good art, because bad art documents human failure.  32.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I don't know about this Tristan RГ©veur guy. I think you ought to choose your role models a little more carefully. (beat; very sober now) You do understand that I'm required by law to report anyone who physically threatens himself or others? Henry laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's funny?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You take all this so seriously.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Should I not take it seriously? Is that what you're telling me? Is this a joke?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about Saturday. I am going to die on Saturday. I just mean your role. The psychiatrist. You play it well. Sam considers this for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Why do you think I'm playing a role? Henry smiles but does not answer.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you playing a role? The Suicidal Romantic? why'd you choose that role? Why do you want to die? The smile disappears from Henry's face. He rubs his palm the burns on his forearm.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don't want to keep hurting people.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Who did you hurt?  33.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don't know. Henry is becoming more and more distraught. He stares at floor, picks at his fingernails. But Sam won't let it res he knows he's on to something important.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Have you done something, Henry? You've hurt someone?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You do know. What have you done? Henry, still staring at the floor, begins to shake his he violently.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that why you're thinking about suicide? Is that it? You need to punish yourself? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don't remember.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You don't want to remember. But you have to. You can't escape from the truth. Whatever it is you've done, you have to face it. Suddenly Henry stops shaking his head and looks straight Sam, a strange smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: If I can't escape from the truth we're all in serious trouble, Dr. Foster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and DR. LEON PATTERSON, a middle-aged blind man weari dark glasses, sit on folding chairs, facing each other ov fold-away chess table. A small radio on the grass plays Billy Holiday. Sam moves queen.  34.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Queen to g4.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Billy Holiday. I remember her singing at the Five Spot, years ago.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I wish I could have heard her

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Yes. Well, I wish I could have seen her.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Here, I want to show you something. Give me your hand. Sam pulls a small, pale-blue Tiffany's box from his blaze pocket, opens it, pulls out a diamond ring and hands it t Leon. Leon rotates the ring between his fingers and rubs the st

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: It's certainly a very hard diamond.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: That's what I asked for. I said, "Give me the hardest diamond you've got." Leon hands the ring back to Sam and then claps him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Sam. I'm very happy for you. Does she know? Sam returns the ring to his blazer pocket.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Not yet. I want the mood to be right before I propose. The last few days... I'm having a hard time with one of Beth Levy's patients. He wants to kill himself Saturday night.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Henry Letham.  35.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (surprised) You know him?

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Beth told me about him. He's been planning this suicide for quite some time. The good news is, he's still meeting with you. He's looking for help.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You've been shrinking heads for thirty years. I figured you could give me some ideas.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Knight to c3. Check. Sam moves Leon's knight for him and studies the chess boa

dialogues.speaker: LEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you remember the dream of the burning boy that Freud refers to?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Vaguely.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Vaguely meaning no?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: He describes a man whose child is dying. The father sits by the boy's bed, night after night, mopping the sweat from the boy's forehead bringing him water to drink. All for nothing. After the child dies, they give him a wake, set up a circle of candles around his body. The father is exhausted, of course. He goes to sleep in the next room. And he dreams that his boy stands beside him, holding his arm and whispering, "Father, can't you see that I'm burning?" When the man wakes up he runs into the next room and sees that one of the candles has fallen onto the shroud and set the dead boy on fire.  36.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He noticed the heat or the light and his unconscious figured out a fire had started.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Probably. That's the logical explanation. But what's interesting, what interested Freud, is the way the father's unconscious dealt with that knowledge. Some part of him knew that a fire had started, but rather than waking immediately he created a dream- version of his child, to act asa messenger.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He wanted his boy alive again. The fire could wait a moment, he wanted his boy to stay with him. what made you think of it? Leon smiles, tapping his cane on the floor in time with t beat.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: I never stop thinking about it. I heard that story fifty years ago and I still can't get it out of my mind. Our imagination wants to protect us from everything. A shadow falls over the chess board and Sam turns around. Henry stands behind him, staring at Leon. Henry's face is even paler than usual, his eyes wide in disbelief. Sam stands and grips Henry's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Henry! Didn't expect to see you. Do you know Doctor Patterson? Leon rises from his chair and extends his hand in Henry's direction.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Hello, Henry. Henry ignores the offered hand. He can't take his eyes of the old man's face.  37.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (to Henry) What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (to Leon, in a dazed whisper ) What are you doing here? Leon is confused, unsure whether he's being spoken to or He withdraws his extended hand.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You're dead. Leon is puzzled for a moment but smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Not yet, I'm happy to say. Dr. Foster, I'll leave you two in peace. We'll finish the game later yes? Leon walks away, tapping the ground before him with his c

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Are you all right? Here, take a seat. Henry remains standing. He watches Leon disappear around corner before turning on Sam.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You're playing games with me.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Nobody's playing games.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (furious) Why did you bring him here? Are you torturing me?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Henry- -

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What are you doing to me?  38.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: That's my father, goddamn you. Sam stares at Henry for a moment and then sits.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Dr. Patterson never married. He has no children.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I know my father.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Listen--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You think I wouldn't recognize my own father?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I thought you told me your father was dead.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He is dead. He died and they buried him and that was him sitting here.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Henry, think about it for a minute. Dr. Patterson is alive and well. Henry doesn't say anything for a while. He rubs his scarr forearms in silence. Finally, gesturing at the campus abo them, the buildings and trees and students:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Everything you believe is a lie.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Then tell me the truth. Henry closes his eyes for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Your troubles will cease and fortune will smile upon you. Sam stares at the student, perplexed.  39.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Where did that come from? But Henry is already walking away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and a CUSTODIAN stand by the entrance. A specially-ma Mobile Crisis Unit ambulance pulls up. Dr. Schlegel steps out, followed by the two burly paramedics from before.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: We can't wait any longer.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL
dialogues.text: Let's do it. All four men enter the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam knocks on the door to room 313. There is no sound fro within. The custodian flips through the keys on his massive key r The other men wait in silence.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTODIAN
dialogues.text: Here we go. He slips the master key into the lock and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is very dark. The custodian walks over to a wind and pulls the shade up. Weak sunlight streams in.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTODIAN
dialogues.text: Jesus. The room is small and almost empty: there is a bare mattr in one corner and a chair by the window. A phone and answering machine are on the chair. Every inch of the walls and ceiling is covered with minus handwriting, an endless loop of black ink. Sam steps clos to the wall and examines it. The phrase FORGIVE ME repeated again and again and again.  40. The paramedics exchange glances. Dr. Schlegel studies the handwriting carefully. Something on the floor catches his and he stoops to pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL
dialogues.text: Trouble. Dr. Schlegel hands a small box to Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam walks over to the answering machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The number 1 is flashing in the LED display. Sam looks at Dr. Schlegel, who nods. Sam pushes the play button. For a moment there is nothing but static. In the backgrou we hear a murmur of voices and distant sirens. After a fe seconds of this a female voice:

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Stay Henry stay stay stay Henry stay stay stay Henry stay stay stay Henry stay stay stay Henry stay stay stay Henry stay stay stay Henry stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Dr. Schlegel stand alone on the steps while the paramedics stand in front of the ambulance, smoking cigarettes and watching the COLLEGE GIRLS stroll by.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL
dialogues.text: Not much we can do at this point. We don't have the manpower for a stakeout or anything like that. I'll notify the police but they won't do anything.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Why not?  41.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL
dialogues.text: Because they're New York City cops, that's why not. They've got more important things to do than look for depressed college students.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Then I'll find him.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL
dialogues.text: Okay. If you spot him, give me a call and we'll pick him up for you. But do me a favor, Sam?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SCHLEGEL
dialogues.text: Be careful. A guy this far gone's got nothing to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on the ramp leading up to the Brooklyn Bridge. The Gothic towers, massive and imposing, rise above us. It's late, traffic is light, and we're moving fast

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry sits, head bowed, eyes closed, in a forward pew of enormous cathedral. An enthusiastic blonde TOUR GUIDE is leading a group of Midwestern TOURISTS up the nave, point out the sights.

dialogues.speaker: TOUR GUIDE
dialogues.text: The largest stained glass window, above the entry-way -- looks like a kaleidoscope, doesn't it? -- contains over three thousand separate pieces of glass. Some of the best craftsmen from around the world have worked on the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, but it's a long way from finished. It won't be complete for at least another century. The tour group exits the cathedral, leaving Henry alone i the building. He raises his head toward the ceiling.  42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roof of the cathedral is so high, and the lighting so poor, that it's impossible to see the ceiling. From somewhere inside the building a BABY'S howl echoes. Henry looks around, wondering where the sound is coming f He gets up and begins to follow the noise. Everywhere he goes statues of the saints stare down at hi unsmiling. No matter where he stands, the baby's howl seems just as away. He walks up the nave, toward the entrance. The cathedral is very dark, the nave very long. His foots echo off the stone walls. Finally he reaches daylight and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry examines the hallucinogenic peace fountain on the cathedral's grounds. Saint Michael, winged and victorious sword-wielding, has just decapitated Satan, whose headles body is plunging into the abyss. Henry walks over to the fenced-off garden behind the Peac Fountain. The one PEACOCK in Manhattan lives in this gard Henry, behind the fence, watches it strutting about, fann its gorgeous array of feathers.

dialogues.speaker: BOY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mommy, is that man going to die? Henry wheels about. The small BOY we last saw holding a r balloon stands a few yards away, holding his MOTHER'S han He has a new red balloon. Both mother and child stare at Henry. Finally the mother her son away, but the child continues to stare over his shoulder at Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam sits at the kitchen table. The documents, from Henry' folder are spread out before him: transcripts, applicatio materials, etc.  43. Sam studies a passport photograph of Henry for a moment t continues to sift through the material while Lila, sittin the opposite side of the table, eats take-out Chinese foo

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (examining a memo) He refused to take the mandatory swim test. Maybe he's afraid of water.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: (chewing) Mm.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Citations for Studio Art. Apparently he's an accomplished painter.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Did you ever hear from Beth Levy?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No. Listen to this: "Of all the students I have encountered at Columbia, Henry Letham has the most fertile imagination. If he maintains his concentration he will create new worlds with his art."

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Clearly that professor wants to fuck Henry Letham. Sam, still paging through the documents, laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: There's the graduate student cynicism I know and love.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: What exactly are you doing, baby? Sam looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: You're letting this kid take over your life. It's not your job to track down missing students.  44. Sam is quiet for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Whose job is it?

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: I just don't think it's healthy to be so obsessed with one patient.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I don't think it's healthy, either. But if I don't help him, no one else will. He's alone in the world.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Maybe you're right. Maybe I ama cynic. But it seems to me that he's using you. (beat) You want your fortune cookie?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: It's all yours. Lila cracks open the cookie and pulls out the fortune.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: (reading) "Your troubles will cease and fortune will smile upon you." Sam slowly looks up at her. All the color has drained fro his face.

dialogues.speaker: LILA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And not a moment too soon, that's all I can say. (noticing Sam's expression) What's the matter, baby? Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam stands outside an apartment door, holding the Henry Letham folder. He rings the doorbell. No answer. He rings again. He bangs on the door. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (yelling) Beth? Finally the door opens, still chained.  45.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (quieter) Beth? It's Sam. Are you okay? DR. BETH LEVY unchains the door and walks back into the apartment. Frizz-haired and overweight, Beth looks bad. S obviously hasn't showered in days, or changed her clothes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam follows her inside, closing the door behind him. The light in the apartment is from the streetlights. Beth sits on the floor, her back against a sofa.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: How you feeling? I'm sorry, I should have come earlier Beth is not paying any attention to him. Sam sits down a feet away from her.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Beth? (forcing a laugh) They've got you doped up on some serious painkillers, huh? what are you on, Vicodin? Percoset?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: There was no surgery.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What do you mean? The appendectomy- - they decided not to operate?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I made it up.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You... why?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Do you want to play? Can we play a kissing game? She begins crawling toward him on her hands and knees.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT' D)
dialogues.text: I always wanted to kiss you. Let's play a kissing game. Okay?  46. Sam holds up his hands.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Beth... She stops abruptly and sinks back on her haunches.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: No, I'm too old for you. I'm too fat. You like them young and skinny, don't you? Like that little slut you live with.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Stop. Beth's face seems on the verge of collapse.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Don't hate me, Sam. Please don't hate me.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: How could I hate you?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Not that it matters. Not that any of it matters.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: This has something to do with Henry Letham. Beth laughs very hard. It is not a pleasant sound.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, yes, it does! Hurrah, you win! It does have something to do with Henry Letham. You win the grand prize. Very good, very good, ten points. Thank you for playing, Henry. Sam cocks his head and looks at her more closely.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: It's Sam.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I remember you. Sad, sad Sam. Henry's got quite an imagination doesn't he? I remember you. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETH(cont 'd) I remember cleaning your bathroom floor, on my hands and knees between the tiles, behind the sink everywhere. Sam is speechless for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: That was twenty years ago. What does that have to do with Henry?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Everything has to do with Henry.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You know he's planning to kill himself this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: No more Mondays, anyway. That's the good news. I never liked Mondays. We played make-believe. Didn't we? We played make-believe for so many years. Except it wasn't us playing.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Do you know where I can find him? Beth?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Ask his mother.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: His mother? His mother's dead.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Ask her anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam has managed to get Beth into bed. She sleeps now whil Sam sits at the foot of the bed, looking through papers f Henry's folder. He dials a number on his CELL PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hello? Yes,. I'm sorry to bother you at this hour. My name is Dr Sam Foster, I'm a psychiatrist at Columbia University. Yes. I'm calling about a student named Henry Letham.  48. Sam listens.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He's your son? He... I'm sorry, this is very strange. He told me you had died... Hello? Hello? Sam stares at the cell phone. He dials the number again a listens. Nobody answers.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You have no idea what's going on do you? Sam turns and sees Beth sitting up in bed, watching him. is calmer now, but her eyes are still bloodshot and wild.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He lied to me.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Trust me, Sam-- the truth is worse than the lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch the battered old Volvo glide over the Hudson beneath the lighted suspension cables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam drives down dark New Jersey back roads. He pull into the driveway of a small, rundown house. No lights are on inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam checks the address on the form in Henry's folder. He looks up, sees 9625 on the mailbox. He parks the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam gets out of the car and walks to the doorstep. The ho is dark. Sam rings the doorbell. No answer. He rings agai

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I've been waiting for you.  49. Sam spins around. MRS. LETHAM sits in the darkness on a p swing. She wears a silk kerchief around her head, the kin that chemotherapy patients sometimes wear

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Mrs. Letham? I'm Dr. Sam Foster. I called before? (beat) Sorry to bother you at this hour, but it's an emergency.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: I thought you'd never come visit. She stands and approaches Sam. She has a limp. She's a ki looking woman, but weary, with dark circles below her blu eyes and wisps of gray hair straying out from under the kerchief.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I would have called earlier except... to be honest, I didn't even know you were alive.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: I guess it's easy to forget me, all alone out here in the country.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Your son's not well.. That's what I'm here about. I'm trying to find him. He's... he's threatened suicide. Mrs. Letham laughs but the laugh turns into a cough. limps to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: I know why you came. Not because of me. You came to see Olive, didn't you? Sam frowns.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Olive?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: I know you did. She She opens the door, flicks on a light and leads him insid In the light we can see that Mrs. Letham has a wine-stain birthmark on her left cheek.  50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is immaculate. The windows are spotless; the chandelier by the staircase glitters; the hardwood floor polished and gleaming. But there is no furniture to be seen anywhere. Sam and Mr Letham's footsteps echo in the empty house. A black Neapolitan MASTIFF pads into the room and stares the newcomer. The dog is massive, at least 160 pounds slobber-jawed, its black eyes tiny in its huge head.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: Here she is. She's been lonely. Me and Olive keep each other company. It feels like we've been alone in this house for a thousand years.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hey, Olive. How you doing, girl? The mastiff stares at him impassively.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: She doesn't remember you anymore, you've been away so long. (beat) Let me fix you something to eat. I have some leftovers in the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No thank you, I ate. Do you know how to contact your son? Any friends or relatives he might have gone to see? But Mrs. Letham limps into the kitchen anyway and Sam is forced to follow her. Olive pads in after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen shines like the rest of the house. Someone ha spent hours scrubbing every surface until it gleams. Mrs. Letham opens the refrigerator and looks through it.  51. The refrigerator is empty.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: Most days I don't say a single word. I'm silent so long sometimes I forget how to speak. It's so quiet here.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Mrs. Letham, we have an emergency. Henry's in danger. Suddenly, Mrs. Letham seems close to tears. She closes th refrigerator and looks at Sam.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: Do you hate me? You must hate me. Is that why you did it? Because you hate me?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I don't hate you at all. Your son needs help. That's why I'm here. Mrs. Letham smiles and takes Sam's hand.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: I knew you'd come back, eventually. It was so quiet without you, so lonely. But now you've come back and you're never going to leave. Sam is quiet for a moment, searching Mrs. Letham's smilin face.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Who do you think I am, Mrs. Letham?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: Don't play these games anymore. Not anymore.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Who am I?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: You think I don't know you, Henry? You think I don't recognize my only son? Mrs. Letham wraps her arms around Sam and squeezes him to her.  52.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh Lord, I missed you. I missed you so much. I could never stay angry at you. I know you didn't mean to hurt me. Sam nods. He speaks very quietly, very carefully. They ar still locked in an embrace.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: Yes, baby?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: How did I hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter anymore. Let's not talk about it, please.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Where do I go on the weekends?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: You go the city. You've been going to the city since you were old enough to take the train.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: And where do I go in the city? Abruptly, Mrs. Letham goes cool. She breaks off the hug.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: You used to go to your classes before you met Athena.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Athena?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: (increasingly angry) Now you might not even graduate, your grades are so bad.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Do you remember where Athena lives?  53.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: Athena this, Athena that, always Athena, beautiful Athena. I'm sick of Athena! I'm sick of her!

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Mrs. Letham-- Sam abruptly stops talking, seeing what we now see. Blood trickles down the side of Mrs. Letham's face, leaking fro underneath her kerchief. A large drop of the blood falls and splatters on the whit tiled floor. Mrs. Letham sees the blood and grabs a sponge from the si She drops to her knees and begins violently scrubbing at spot on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: How could you? Your own mother, how could you? Meanwhile the blood is beginning to stream down her face. scrubs ferociously but more and more blood spatters on th tiles. Sam kneels beside her.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Let me look at your head. When he reaches for her kerchief she slaps away his hand snarls.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM
dialogues.text: You did this! Olive leaps upon Henry, knocking him to the floor, biting viciously at his face and throat. Sam desperately holds the mastiff off, the slobbering jaw inches from his jugular. Mrs. Letham watches for a few seconds before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Olive! Off! Upon her command the mastiff immediately disengages and retreats. Sam bleeds from the hands, neck, and face.  54.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LETHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You better leave, Henry. You're not welcome anymore.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOSPITAL ROOM-- EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: Saturday Sam sits while an INTERN finishes sewing up the gash on h neck.

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: The Percoset will make you a little drowsy, so--

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I know. SHERIFF KENNELLY knocks on the open door and peeks in.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Dr. Foster? I'm Sheriff Kennelly. Could I have a word with you, sir? The intern drops the needle into the biohazard waste receptacle and exits the room.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got bit up pretty good. Got your rabies shot already?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yes. Sheriff Kennelly pages through a notebook.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Now, I've been looking through the report Deputy Carlyle gave me. And I just wanted to check on something. You said the assault took place at 9625 Rickover Street?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Home belonging to the Letham family.  55.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Right, her dog attacked me. She's-- Mrs. Letham-- she's very sick right now. She's had some sort of head trauma, and she's showing signs of schizophrenic paranoia. She's all alone and she needs help. She should be in a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: The thing is, Doctor, I knew Maureen Letham. I went to high school with her.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay, well maybe you know her son, then. Henry. He's a patient of mine at Columbia University. That's why I visited her.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Sure, I remember Henry. Pale, skinny kid. Always reading. (laughing uncomfortably) Kind of gave me the creeps.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: That's him.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: What's strange, Doctor, what I'm trying to figure out, is who you were speaking with over at 9625 Rickover Street.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I thought we already established that. Maureen Letham.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: There's a basic problem here I'm trying to work out. See, I mentioned I went to high school with Maureen Letham. I also went to her funeral. She's been dead for six months. Sam stares at the sheriff, dumbfounded.  56.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Car wreck. Her and her husband. As far as I know, that house is empty still. The family's trying to sell it.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I was talking to Maureen Letham last night. We were talking about her son.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Well, it's probably just someone's confused. How long they keeping you here?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I've got to head back to the city as soon as possible. Listen, 9625 Rickover Street: I was there. Henry's mother was there. The sheriff stares at Sam. Finally he nods and stuffs his notebook into his jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: All right, Dr. Foster, we'll be in touch. I've got your number The sheriff turns to leave. When he's halfway down the corridor, Sam calls out to him.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Yep?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Maureen Letham. Did she have a birthmark right here? Sam points to his left cheek. The sheriff squints at Sam.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Yes sir, she did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry walks down one of the few blocks near Times Square still looks like the old Times Square: erotic bookshops, shows, adult theaters.  57. Everyone else on the street is dressed for the cold night but Henry still wears the same T-shirt he's had on all da He doesn't seem to notice the cold. He looks up at the marquee of a porn movie theater. INT.

dialogues.speaker: PORNO THEATER
dialogues.text: He walks down the aisle and finds a seat in the front row hear the soundtrack: the usual moans and gasps over the u cheesy music.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We watch Henry's face bathe in the flickering light from screen. Henry looks weary. His hair lies flat and wet across his scalp. Now, below the synthesized music and the grunting hear a low and distant thump. The thump slowly gets louder-- it's a heartbeat. Louder a louder until all other sound is masked. Finally we see the screen. A FETUS curled up within its mother's womb, silently swimming in the amniotic fluid. We pull back to see the other viewers in the theater. Man them are asleep, street people who went inside to escape cold. Those still awake stare at the screen as if nothing stran were happening. A grizzled old VETERAN in an army jacket. TEENS from the suburbs, wearing their varsity jackets. An OBESE MAN, peering through coke-bottle lenses. And we go back to Henry, who sits silently watching the screen. Back on screen, a montage of a life in the form of brief clips from what could have been home movies. A hospital nurse presents the baby boy to his mother. The rattles the bars of his crib. The boy takes his first ste

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Stop. In each new image the boy is slightly older. Sledding dow snowy hill. Blowing out candles on a cake. Henry turns to look at the projector, lighting the screen with its story.  58.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please stop it. On screen: the boy raising his hand in class. Down by the shore, throwing a tennis ball for Olive (the mastiff look exactly like she did when we first saw her). Kissing a gi for the first time (judging from his closed eyes and hesi pucker). Reading a novel. Stealing second base. Drinking whiskey with his friends. Henry, tormented by what he sees on screen, keeps looking back at the projector's white light.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop! Stop! Turn it off! On screen: the boy smoking a cigarette (and now, if we haven't before, we recognize that it's a younger Henry on screen). Arriving for his first day of freshman year at Columbia. Shooting pool with friends in a smoky bar. Sitt in the bleachers cheering for the New York Yankees.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beginning to sob) Stop! Stop! Walking down Broadway with the GREEN-EYED WOMAN, whom we recognize from the driver's POV sequences. Driving across the Brooklyn Bridge with the green-eyed wo and two passengers in back whose faces we can't make out.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT' D)
dialogues.text: (sobbing; barely able to speak) Stop... stop... A terrible noise fills the theater-- steel colliding with steel at high speed. The screen goes black. Henry bolts up from his seat and runs from the theater. After a few seconds, two words appear on the bottom of th screen, a subtitle. FORGIVE ME. The subtitle does not fade away. The men in the theater s at the screen. Nobody says a word.  59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam parks his car down the block from his building and wa toward home. Halfway there he stops to watch piano movers work across the street. They are the same piano movers we saw before, and they se to be hauling the same piano into the same apartment

dialogues.speaker: PIANO MOVER 1
dialogues.text: Easy, easy. Sam stops in his tracks. He has been here before. A small boy, accompanied by his mother, runs down the str holding a red balloon. He trips and falls and the balloon begins to float away.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Wait! Wait! The workmen hear the boy's cries and see the balloon. Pia Mover 1 makes a valiant effort to capture the escaping balloon: he runs after it and leaps... but he can't quite reach it. Sam stares at the rising balloon in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: PIANO MOVER 1
dialogues.text: Sorry, kid. It's gone to balloon heaven. Everything but the time of day is the same: the cars in t street, the kid's crestfallen expression, the red balloon disappearing into the gray sky. Sam runs across the street and confronts Piano Mover 1.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You were here on Thursday. You were moving this piano on Thursday, too. The man is engaged in the difficult business of hoisting piano into a fourth-floor apartment and doesn't have time this kind of banter. He looks briefly at Sam and then back to the Bechstein.

dialogues.speaker: PIANO MOVER 1
dialogues.text: Can I help you with something, pal?  60.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: That kid with the balloon, the exact same thing happened on Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: PIANO MOVER 1
dialogues.text: We're a little busy here. why don't you go bother someone else? Sam watches the workmen on the fourth floor ease the pian into position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam staggers in the front door, exhausted. Lila comes out the bedroom. She stops in her tracks when she sees him, a bandaged and battered, then hurries over to him.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: What happened to you? Sam shakes his head. How can he possibly explain what has happened to him? He limps toward the bedroom. Lila, nonplussed, follows after him.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: I was calling people all over the city looking for you. I was about to call the police. Sam checks the clock: 8:12 a.m. He begins to undress, pul off his sweater.

dialogues.speaker: LILA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's going on, Sam? Sam sits on the edge of the bed, considering the question

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: I don't know? You run out in the middle of the night and don't come back until eight in the morning, no phone call, no explanation, looking like someone tried to murder you? Don't tell me I don't know.  61. Sam lies down on the bed, his clothes half-removed. He's exhausted to have a real conversation, too bewildered by events of the last few hours, too numbed from the Percose

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You want a better answer, ask someone else.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Lila, I'm seeing things that don't make any sense. Okay? I'm meeting people that are supposed to be dead,. Beth Levy's had a nervous breakdown and this kid I'm supposed to be treating knows what's going to happen before it happens.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
