dialogues.text: You were at Beth Levy's all night? Sam groans.

dialogues.speaker: LILA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're losing me, Sam. I swear to God, you're starting to lose me. Sam grunts, already half-asleep.

dialogues.speaker: LILA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (heavy sarcasm) I'm glad we had this conversation. I think we really cleared the air on some important issues. (jangling the car keys) I'm going to the library.

dialogues.speaker: SAM'S FIRST DREAM
dialogues.text: The screen goes black. And then bright white. The white gradually resolves and we see that we're staring into the glare of a small flashlight. The flashlight disappears and Sam's face replaces it, Sam face looming large, staring directly into the camera.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Can you hear me, Henry? Henry? I'm a doctor, I'm going to help you. Can you hear me?  62.

dialogues.speaker: END OF SAM'S FIRST DREAM
dialogues.text: Sam opens his eyes. He's lying on his bed, still half- clothed. He looks at the clock. 3 p.m. He sits straight u He's running out of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam prepares to leave, after having showered and changed clothes (though he still wears the sweater he always wear He looks at himself in the foyer mirror. His eyes are haunted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam pushes the elevator button and waits. The door slides open. Henry stands there. He slept on the street and it shows. stumbles backward.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. (beat) What are you doing here? How did you know where I live? The doors start to slide shut and Sam gets into the eleva They descend.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've been looking all over for you. I saw your mother last night. Henry seems uninterested.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You told me she was dead. Henry stares at Sam, never blinking.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everyone seems to think your mother's dead. But I was standing in her kitchen talking to her. Sam indicates the bandages on his neck.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I met Olive.  63.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Olive's dead, too. We put her to sleep when I was twelve. She had a tumor in her liver.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Olive's not dead. She is very much not dead.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: She was a good girl. She used to kill the rabbits. Sam grabs Henry and presses him against the wall of the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Quit playing with me.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (with mock surprise) Doctor Foster!

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I want to know what's going on. How do you know the future?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I make it up. The door opens onto the seventh-floor. A MUSLIM WOMAN in veil looks into the elevator. Sam releases Henry. The wom decides not to get in. Everyone is silent until the doors slide shut again.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Ever since I met you impossible things have been happening. I'm trying to help you but it feels like I'm losing my mind. (beat) What happened to your parents? Henry shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There's something you want to tell me. Why can't you admit that? If you just wanted to kill yourself, you'd have already done it. So why don't you? Why do you keep coming to me?  64.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Because you're the only one who can help me. Henry looks down at the cigarette burns marking his forea

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want to know why I keep burning my, arms?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I want to see if I'll feel any pain.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Nothing. Sam looks up at the floor indicator lights. Henry looks u well. 3...2...1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit the elevator in the lobby and stand in front of mirrored wall.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I showed you my scars. Now let's see yours. Sam frowns and touches the bandage on his neck but Henry shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, your old scars. Sam is silent.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, don't be shy.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: How do you know about that? Henry says nothing. Finally Sam rolls up the cuffs of his shirt. He holds his arms in front of him, palms up.  65. Three narrow scars carve up each wrist. Henry looks at th for a moment and then Sam rolls the cuffs back and button them.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: First year of medical school. I read somewhere you're supposed to do it in warm water, to make the blood flow quicker. I was always a good reader. So I filled the tub and I cut my wrists and I waited. Beth Levy found me. She was in the room across the hall, she came over to borrow a textbook. She dragged me out of the bath and she put tourniquets on my arms and she called an ambulance. I'd lost six pints of blood by then, but they saved me. They sewed me up and I was good as new. For the first time, Sam has Henry's complete attention. T young man stares intently at Sam, waiting for the rest.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was in the hospital two weeks. Beth came in every night and sat with me for a few hours. She was my only visitor. I didn't feel like talking. Not to Beth, not to anyone. So she didn't talk. She sat in the corner of the room, knitting. Beth's not a natural with the knitting needles. I mean, she's maybe the smartest human being I've ever met, but this was not one of her skills. She never stopped though. She'd screw up all the time, she'd have to unravel the whole night's work, but she never stopped. Do you know how good it felt to have her in there? Not talking, not giving me advice, not doing anything but being there with me. Henry looks at Sam's navy-blue cable-knit sweater.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: The sweater you always wear  66.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (nodding) The morning the hospital released me, she came to give me a ride home. She looked exhausted. I guess she stayed up the whole night. She handed me the sweater and said, "Ta- da! Finished!" I tried it on and it fit, perfectly. And she said-

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: "It's cold outside, Sam." Sam stares at Henry.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: She told you the story?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Maybe I told her the story.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What the hell does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You're leaving something out aren't you? You never told me why.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Why I slit my wrists? Sam thinks about it for a moment and then shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought everything was a lie. The whole world was a lie.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What if it is? Sam shrugs again.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What if it is? It's not worth dying over.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why not? Why live if everything you believe turns out to be a lie?  67.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Because it's a beautiful lie. (beat) And I want to see what comes next. Henry shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No. You don't. He starts to leave but Sam grabs him by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I can't let you go, Henry. I'm taking you to the hospital. Sam begins leading Henry out the door.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Get your hands off me.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I can't do that. Henry pulls a revolver from his waistband (the bulk of it been hidden below his T-shirt). He presses the muzzle aga Sam's neck.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I think you can.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Let me help you, Henry. Let me try. Henry says nothing but Sam sees the look in his eyes and releases his arm.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You want to know what happened to my parents? I killed them. I killed my mother, I killed my father. (beat) I'm going to Hell.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I don't believe in Hell.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But I do, Dr. Foster. I think we're already there. Henry walks out the building's front door.  68. Sam takes a deep breath. He stares at his reflection in t mirrored wall. After another moment he steels himself and walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Henry- - But Henry is nowhere in sight. Sam looks around, trying t spot him, but he's gone. A taxi waits at a red light. Sam runs over to it and clim into the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Canal Street. A diner. The CABBIE, a middle-aged Filipino wearing a Mets cap, tu and raises his eyebrows at Sam.

dialogues.speaker: CABBIE
dialogues.text: Which diner? There's maybe twenty-- Sam hands the cabbie two twenties.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Just keep the meter running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam jumps out of the taxi and hurries into the diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam approaches WAITRESS 1.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Is there an Athena working here?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS 1
dialogues.text: Yeah. Athena! Sam raises his eyebrows, amazed that the search was so ea  69. A bull-necked BUTCH COOK wearing a dirty apron, her grey shaved to the scalp, a buxom mermaid tattooed on her thic forearm, pushes open the kitchen door, cleaver in her han

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH COOK
dialogues.text: Yeah, what?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Athena?

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH COOK
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Are you a waitress?

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH COOK
dialogues.text: Do I look like a goddamn waitress? I'm the cook.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Right, my mistake. I'm very sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and the cabbie work their way east on Canal Street, stopping at every diner but finding no green-eyed Athena. It's getting darker and darker and time is running out. The wind picks up and rain starts to fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam ends up at a rundown old diner on the corner of Canal Allen. The cabbie drives off. This is the last diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam seats himself at the counter. Outside it's pouring.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Is there a waitress here named Athena?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS 2
dialogues.text: Athena? Nah, never heard of her.  70.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: All right. Could I just get a cup of coffee, please? Sam reaches into his blazer pocket for his wallet and fee something else. He pulls out the engagement ring and turns it in the ligh watching the diamond sparkle.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS 3, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You planning on proposing to Athena? Sam looks up. Waitress 3 apparently overheard his previou conversation. He pockets the ring.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No, I'm-- do you know her? We're talking about the same Athena? Green eyes?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS 3
dialogues.text: You a cop?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No, no, nothing like that. More like a matchmaker. I know a guy who really likes her but he's shy.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS 3
dialogues.text: She doesn't work here anymore. But she's in my acting class.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: She is? Could you--

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS 3
dialogues.text: What are you, a stalker?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No, honestly, look... He pulls out his wallet, removes a photo I.D., and shows to her.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See, I'm a psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS 3
dialogues.text: (examining I.D.) You're a psychiatrist, huh? So you can give Valium prescriptions?  71.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I could give them to a patient of mine who needed them, yes.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS 3
dialogues.text: Okay. Good luck finding Athena. She walks away. Sam stares at her back and then up at the clock on the wall, which reads 7:30. Sam looks at Waitres and takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cramped stage in front of several rows of seats. ATHENA (the green-eyed woman from the DRIVER'S POV sequences and LIFE MONTAGE) and DEVON, a young man with bleached hair, stand on stage, rehearsing. Sam enters through a door in back.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: What have you, my good friends deserved at the hands of Fortune that she sends you to prison hither?

dialogues.speaker: DEVON
dialogues.text: Prison, my lord? Sam sits in the back row and watches. His hair is wet fro the rain.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Denmark's a prison.

dialogues.speaker: DEVON
dialogues.text: Then is the world one.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: A goodly one; in which there are many confines, wards, and dungeons Denmark being one o'th'worst.

dialogues.speaker: DEVON
dialogues.text: We think not so, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Why, then 'tis none to you. For there is nothing either good or bad but thinking makes it so. To me it is a prison.  72.

dialogues.speaker: DEVON
dialogues.text: Prison, my lord? Athena grins and shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Denmark's a prison. We already had this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: DEVON
dialogues.text: Oh, crap. Um...

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: (prompting) Why, then your ambition--

dialogues.speaker: DEVON
dialogues.text: Why, then your ambition makes it one. 'Tis too narrow for your mind.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: O God, I could be bounded in a nutshell and count myself a king of infinite space, were it not that I have bad dreams. (normal speaking voice) That's my favorite line in the whole play.

dialogues.speaker: DEVON
dialogues.text: Good line. I better get home and rest the pipes. I've got a solo in choir tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Thanks for reading with me. You're a good Rosencrantz.

dialogues.speaker: DEVON
dialogues.text: You're a good Hamlet. Devon grabs his satchel from the side of the stage and wa out. Sam stands and walks down to the stage, where Athena packing up her things.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I always pictured Hamlet as a man.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: That's a bit narrow-minded of you, isn't it? This is the lesbian Hamlet. All the parts are played by women.  73.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oh. That's... new.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: I'm joking. I'm Ophelia. I just get so sick of playing her. Lovely, lost Ophelia. Things get tough and she jumps in the drink. Hamlet hogs all the good lines.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's notorious for that.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: We've met before, haven't we?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I don't think so. He offers his hand and they shake.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sam Foster.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Athena. Are you joining the class? It's good. Kenny's a bit of a dictator, but you get used to him. Athena pulls on her sweater.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No. I've been looking for you actually.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: That's flattering. Please tell me you're a casting director.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: A psychiatrist, unfortunately. I... I have a patient who likes you very much. Athena smiles, but clearly she's not thrilled by this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: This is an unusual way of getting a date. What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Henry Letham.  74.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) Never heard of him.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I was hoping you might know where to find him. He mentioned you once. He has a crush on you. You served him coffee in a diner, you were nice to him. The way he tells it you were the one good thing that ever happened to him.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Henry. Is he very pale? Very thin and very pale? His arms are scarred?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You remember him?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: He always ate pecan pie with his coffee. I remember that. But we never spoke outside the diner. Except...

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What? Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: I feel stupid saying this stuff to a psychiatrist. You'll think I'm insane. But I had the strangest feeling about him. I mean, he's this ragged-looking guy, probably hasn't bathed in months, but something about him... I'd seen him before, somewhere. I'd known him. What's wrong with him? Sam hesitates for a moment. This is privileged informatio after all, which he is loathe to disclose. But there's no time left for playing by the rules.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He's going to kill himself at midnight. Athena opens her mouth to speak, closes it, then opens it again.  75.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He seems to believe he did something terrible. And he thinks this is the only way he can make up for it. That's my guess, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: I wish there was something I could do. Actually... this probably won't help, but I did run into him one night at A. Smith's.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: A. Smith's?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: The art bookstore. He was sitting in the back, reading. I don't know, maybe he hangs out there. It's nearby. Come on, I'll show you. She leads Sam out the side door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very dark, narrow alley piled with trash. Somewhere nea a BABY is howling. The storm has died down but a drizzle continues, and rainwater drips from the overhanging fire escapes.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: I know, it's gross. Sam steps in a puddle and looks down.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Christ. He steps out of the puddle and looks up. Athena is nowher sight.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Athena? The alley seems to be darker and narrower than before; th streetlights shining from the head, of the alley seem far away .  76.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Athena? He begins jogging forward. After a few steps he slips ona wet wrapper and falls backwards onto the trash-strewn pavement, banging his head. For a moment everything is dark

dialogues.speaker: SAM'S SECOND DREAM
dialogues.text: Sam's face suddenly fills the screen. He is staring direc into the camera.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Come on, kid, you need to stay conscious. Come on, come on, stay with me.

dialogues.speaker: END OF SAM'S SECOND DREAM
dialogues.text: Sam opens his eyes. He's lying on his back in the alleywa He stands, unsteadily, and brushes the dirt from his clot He pats his blazer pocket and realizes it's empty. Panicked, he looks through all his pockets. The RING is g He bends down and tries to find the ring, but there is no light to see anything. He looks up. The only light comes from beneath the side d into the actor's studio. Sam opens the door and lets the light from the studio shi into the alleyway.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why, then 'tis none to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam frowns and leans into the studio. He cannot believe w he sees. On stage, Athena and Devon are performing the same duolog as last time.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: For there is nothing either good or bad but thinking makes it so. To me it is a prison.  77.

dialogues.speaker: DEVON
dialogues.text: Prison, my lord? Athena grins and shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Denmark's a prison. We already had this conversation. Sam legs go weak. He shakes his head back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: DEVON
dialogues.text: Oh, crap. Um...

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (under his breath) No.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: (prompting) Why, then your ambition--

dialogues.speaker: DEVON
dialogues.text: Why, then your ambition makes it one. 'Tis too narrow for your mind.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: O God, I could be bounded in a nutshell and count myself a king of infinite space, were it not that I have bad dreams. Sam bolts, letting the side door close behind him. Neithe Athena nor Devon seem to notice.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's my favorite line in the whole play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're cruising across the Brooklyn Bridge. The driver's h (a man's hands) are on the steering wheel. We turn to the right and see Athena sleeping in the passe seat. The driver's eyes (and the CAMERA) return to the ro Suddenly, and with no warning, everything changes.  78. The car shakes and lurches to the right. We see the hands the wheel desperately trying to control the car, but it's impossible. Through the windshield we see the road spinning away from and then the steel guardrail coming at us far too fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon sits by a partially-opened window, listening to the wind, the rain, the thunder. He sways as he listens, and gestures with his hands, as if he were conducting the sto

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You always loved storms. Leon grabs his cane and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Who's that? How did you get in here? Leon trembles and thrusts at the air in front of him with cane.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's me, Dad. Henry.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? You died. I kissed your cheek at the wake.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: You've got the wrong man. I told you that before. I never had any children.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You don't recognize me. He walks over to Leon, who hears him coming and raises hi cane in fear. Henry grabs the cane and pulls the older ma closer.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm not going to hurt you. He removes Leon's dark glasses. Leon's eyes swim in their sockets: useless, blind eyes.  79.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at me, Dad. Look at me. CLOSE on Leon's eyes. They seem to stabilize, the pupils dilating, beginning to focus, to work. Leon looks directly at Henry now. He reaches out and touc the young man's face. Leon cannot speak. He looks at his own hands, the lines creasing his palms. He looks out the window. A bolt of lightning brightens the night sky and Leon moans.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Lightning.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Do you recognize me now? Leon turns back to the boy. Leon's face is transfixed wit wonder everything he sees is a miracle. He touches Henry' cheek again.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: What are you?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'm your son.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: No-- Henry embraces the older man, buries his face in the psychiatrist's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Is this my punishment, Dad? You won't recognize me?

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: I never had a--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Please, please, Dad. Forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: For killing you. Leon pushes out of the embrace and takes a half step backward.  80.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: I'm alive. Henry shakes his head sadly.

dialogues.speaker: LEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you? Are you a god?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: A god?

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: You perform miracles...

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Miracles? He walks over to the living room wall. One strip of wallp has begun to peel slightly and Henry tears the strip off wall.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think it's a miracle? Words in black ink are scribbled on the bare wall beneath paper.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you see now? Henry tears off an entire sheet of the wallpaper, and the another, and then another, flaying the wall. The phrase FORGIVE ME is written again and again, the familiar endless loop of minuscule, tortured handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you see? It's in my head, Dad. It's all in my head. Leon stares at the writing for several seconds, then turn stare at Henry.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: No--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'm dreaming you. Leon opens his mouth to speak but no words come out.  81.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can't get out of it. I try-- I try to wake up, but I can't. I'm trapped here.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Henry- -

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But I can't die in a dream, right? So if I try to kill myself, I'll end the dream.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: And what happens to us? Henry stares at the older man for a moment and then abrup turns and leaves. Leon limps after him.

dialogues.speaker: LEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happens to us?! What happens to us?! Henry opens the apartment door and slams it shut behind h Leon looks at the closed door for a moment and then out t window, where the lightning is becoming more and more frequent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sprawling old bar in the West Village. Henry, soaking w from the rain, pushes open the door and enters. The barro is nearly empty. He approaches the bar. The BARTENDER is a heavily-muscled bruiser paging through bodybuilding MAGAZINE.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You got I.D.? Henry takes his driver's license out of his wallet and th bartender inspects it carefully. The clock on the wall re 9:05.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (smiling) Happy birthday, kid. First one's on the house.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: A shot of Jack with a Bud back.  82.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: An All-American drinker, that's what I like to see. Coming right up.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Isn't this where Dylan Thomas had his last drink?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: (serving the shot and beer) Yep. He lined up eighteen shots, downed them all, and said, "There, I think that's a record." Then he dropped dead. "Do not go gentle into that good night." Henry raises his shot glass to the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: "Rage, rage against the dying of the light." Henry gulps down the shot and pounds the glass onto the b

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eighteen more for the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, shell shocked, walks slowly down the block. He looks into the face of every person he passes. A light rain continues to fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every shade of humanity is represented in the quickly pas faces. The beautiful and the ugly, the rich and the poor, thin and the fat, the happy and the agitated and the expressionless. Each face comes into focus for a second before leaving th frame. Sam stops in front of a storefront. A. SMITH'S is written gold script on the glass.  83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam wanders through the aisles. He checks the back area, where a few STUDENTS sit on the window ledges, paging thr art books. Henry is not here. A bespectacled CLERK approaches Sam.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Can I help you find something?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Henry Letham.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: A book by Henry Letham or on Henry Letham?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No, he's... I thought he might be here. I heard he comes here sometimes. The clerk calls over to SMITTY, the rumpled shop owner, w sits behind the checkout counter paging through a book of photographs.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Smitty, you know a guy named Henry Letham?

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: Sure. (he looks at Sam) Something happen to him?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I need to find him. It's an emergency.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: I keep telling the kid to get some sun. It's not healthy spending all your time in bookstores. (laughing) Look at me.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You haven't seen him tonight?  84.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: Nah, he hasn't been by in weeks. You're his father?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No, I... I teach up at Columbia.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: You're his art teacher? Kid's got talent. I have one of his paintings here somewhere. Smitty ducks below the counter and begins delving through drawers.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (crouching) Here we go. He stands and spreads an unframed CANVAS over the counter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a very dark, haunting interpretation of the Brooklyn Bridge at night. The perspective is unusual, looking stra up the Gothic arches-- the view you would have if you wer lying flat on your back on the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He didn't have any money for the books he wanted, so he gave me this. I think I got a pretty good deal.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What books did he get?

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: Tristan RГ©veur. What else? The kid is obsessed with Tristan RГ©veur. Maybe he got that from your class.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I doubt it. Do you have any more Tristan RГ©veur books?

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: Nah, he bought me out. It was all secondhand, out-of-print stuff. So what do you think? Is he gonna make it?  85.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What? Smitty indicates the painting.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: You think he's got what it takes? Sam stares at the painting and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry is drunk. A row of empty shot glasses is lined up before him. The clock reads 10:03. The Band's "I Shall be Released" plays over the stereo system.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Could you change the station? They never quit playing this song. The bartender raises his eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: First time I heard it in years. He changes the station.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Where is everybody?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: I guess the rain scared people away .

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's my birthday. I want some company. A crew of soaked TOURISTS stumble into the bar. They spea German. HAUSER, their leader, a tall blonde man with mutt chop sideburns and a bead necklace, approaches the barten

dialogues.speaker: HAUSER
dialogues.text: Is this the place of death of Dylan Thomas?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: HAUSER
dialogues.text: Ah!  86. He turns to his friends and announces the news in German. They all say Ah! and nod happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Germans and Henry sit in a circle, all of them very drunk. Hauser is reciting a Thomas poem. He has a strong accent but he gets every word right.

dialogues.speaker: HAUSER
dialogues.text: And death shall have no dominion. Dead men naked they shall be one With the man in the wind and the west moon... Meanwhile, Henry pulls the heavy black revolver from the pocket of his overcoat and places it on the bar. The bartender, reading his muscle magazine at the far end the bar, does not notice. Nor do the Germans.

dialogues.speaker: HAUSER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When their bones are picked clean and the clean bones gone, They shall have stars at elbow and foot... Henry reaches back into his pocket and dumps six bullets the bar.

dialogues.speaker: HAUSER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Though they go mad they shall be sane, Though they sink through the sea they shall rise again... Henry opens the gun's cylinder, loads one bullet, spins t cylinder.

dialogues.speaker: HAUSER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Though lovers be lost love shall not; And death shall have no dominion. The other Germans clap and whistle.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You want to play a drinking game? The Germans nod and smile at him but it's clear they have idea what he's talking about. He aims the revolver at his head.  87. The Germans are suddenly very quiet. He pulls the trigger. Click. He offers the gun to Hauser.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You sure you don't want to play?

dialogues.speaker: HAUSER
dialogues.text: (refusing the gun) No, please. This is for drinking game? Henry reopens the cylinder, adds another bullet, spins, presses the barrel to his head.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You hear a click, you drink. You hear a bang, I drink. Henry winks at the German and pulls the trigger. Click.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Drink. Hauser smiles and nods at his comrades. He grabs a full b mug from the bar and downs half of it in a gulp. The bartender looks up, sees what's happening, throws dow his magazine.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, whoa, little brother. What are you doing? Henry doesn't answer. He adds another bullet, spins, aims pulls the trigger. Click. Hauser finishes the beer and places the empty mug on the The other Germans, less confident that this is really a g have slowly begun to back away.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put the gun down, kid. Come on.  88.

dialogues.speaker: HAUSER
dialogues.text: (to bartender) This is a drinking game.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: The hell it is. Another bullet into the cylinder. There are four now. Spi aim, pull. Click.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Drink. Hauser is nervous now. He stares at his comrades, who can only watch fearfully.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, you're falling behind. Hauser grabs another beer and swills it down. Fifth bullet. The same procedure. The bartender is inchin closer to Henry. Henry looks at him. The bartender freeze Click. One of the German women starts crying. Hauser drinks as m as he can but spits some of it up. Henry inserts the sixth bullet into the sixth chamber. He closes the cylinder, is about to spin it, realizes he doe have to, smiles at the Germans, presses the muzzle agains his temple. Henry lowers the pistol. The bartender and the Germans release their breath at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: HAUSER
dialogues.text: It is a joke? It is a toy, yes? It is a toy gun? Henry points the revolver at the bottle of Jack Daniel's sitting on the bar. He pulls the trigger. The bottle explodes. Nobody moves. Henry returns the revolver to his pocket. H bows to the Germans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to America. He walks out of the silent bar.
Sam is making a call from a phone booth. He ignores the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila sits in her study carrel in the deserted library. On desk: stacks of books, a laptop computer, and her cell ph which is ringing. She picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: It's me.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: (coldly) I'm surprised you remember the number. Sam tries to answer but then simply shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Are you in the library?

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Where else? The glamorous life of a graduate student.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Listen, do me a favor. There was an artist named Tristan RГ©veur--

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Am I your research assistant now?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: We don't have time for this. Believe me, we do not have time for this. Tristan RГ©veur. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM(cont'd) I need you to find his biography and tell me where he killed himself.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: You know- -

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Please, Lila.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: All right. It'll take me a minute, hold on. Sam waits on the line. Someone taps on the side of the ph booth, behind Sam. Sam waves the person away but there's another tap. Impatiently, Sam turns around. Leon stands there, smiling in the rain, no longer wearing dark glasses, looking directly into Sam's eyes. Sam stares at Leon for a moment before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Leon?

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: I always thought you had brown eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You can see me?

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: I can see everything. For the first time, I can see everything. Sam cannot speak for a moment. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Henry. It's all because of Henry. Sam shakes his head in stunned disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What's happening to us?

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: The Buddhists had it right the whole time. The world is illusion.  91.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You're telling me we're dreaming?

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: No. Henry's dreaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch a terrible accident from the driver's perspectiv through the windshield: the steel guardrails rush toward and it's too late to swerve. The collision is utterly, eerily silent. The CAMERA'S motion follows the head of the driver, slamm forward and then back, a terrible confusion as the car be to roll, the windshield shattered. In all this chaos we are thrown from the car, but it's impossible to get any sense of our bearings before the SC GOES BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry, soaked by the rain, stands outside a clothes bouti well lit to attract passers-by. He stares through the pla glass window at the immaculately-attired mannequins. A sign posted inside the window reads: EVERYTHING MUST GO

dialogues.speaker: BOY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mommy, is that man going to die? Henry, startled, turns and sees the same boy and mother w encountered several times before. The mother pulls her so closer. They stare at Henry. The boy holds a red balloon. Henry looks down. Blood is dripping from his shirtsleeves down his arms, off his fingertips, splattering on the sidewalk, mixing with the rainwater. He stares at his pal Somewhere nearby a BABY is howling. When Henry looks up again everything on the crowded stree has stopped. The cars and trucks and buses have stopped, people on the sidewalk have stopped.  92. Everyone stares at Henry. Riders on the city bus lean out window and stare at him. Bicycle messengers stare at him. woman walking her dog stares at him, and so does the dog. newspaper vendor stares at him. People sitting ina restaurant look at him through the window. Henry closes his eyes. The puddle of blood by his feet gr larger and larger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gold-lettered title reads: "La Vie de Tristan RГ©veur Lila pulls the book off the shelf and begins skimming thr the final pages. Her cell phone is wedged between her shoulder and her face.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Sam? You there?

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (0. S.)
dialogues.text: Did you find it?

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Yeah. My French is a little rusty. Let's see... oh, he was friends with Marcel Duchamp... here it is. She reads haltingly, translating as she goes.

dialogues.speaker: LILA, (CONT' D)
dialogues.text: "At midnight on the fifteenth of March, RГ©veur strolled calmly to the center of the Brooklyn Bridge, tossed a white rose into the East River, and shot himself in the head. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital and pronounced dead on arrival."

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (on phone) Jesus, the Brooklyn Bridge. (beat) Listen to me. Lila?  93.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: I'm listening.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I don't know where we are anymore. I don't know--

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Baby - -

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I love you. You hear? It's the one thing I know is real. I was put on this world to find you.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: But what's--

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No matter what happens, we'll find each other.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Baby, I don't understand--

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (on phone) We'll find each other. Sam hangs up. Leon gazes with wonder at everything: the headlights, the neon, the pedestrians.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What time is it? Leon presses a button on a black faceless watch he wears. synthesized voice speaks.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Eleven thirty three.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: If Henry dies in his dream, the dream ends. And if the dream ends-- Leon spreads his open hands to indicate the street, the c the world.  94.

dialogues.speaker: LEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All gone. Sam pulls out his wallet, fishes a card from it and hands to Leon.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Call the police and tell them Henry's on the Brooklyn Bridge with a gun. Then call Jeff Schlegel at the Mobile Crisis Unit. Sam runs to the curb and tries to hail a taxi. All of the are occupied.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Saturday night in the rain. You'll never find a cab.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Jesus... Sam sees the subway station on the corner (we're on Eight Avenue and Fourteenth Street). He starts running toward i Leon watches him go and then drops Schlegel's card. It flutters to the sidewalk. Leon walks away, west on Fourteenth Street. He is the onl person on the sidewalk. As he walks farther from the came we see for the first time that hi's feet are bare. In the middle of the block, the streetlight above him flickers and dies. The succeeding streetlights, lined up parallel on opposite sides of the avenue, progressively flicker and die. Leon disappears into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam's riding on the 6 (he took the L to the 6). He's alone in the car, except for a MUSLIM WOMAN in full veil. Sam looks at her. Is she the same woman he saw in h building earlier in the day? She resolutely keeps her gaze on the floor. The express train passes by on the inside track.  95. Sam watches it pass. Each fluorescent-lighted car is empt Except the last car. Henry stands in the last car, holding onto a pole. His eyes meet Sam's. Henry waves goodbye as his train plunges into the tunnel ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam runs up the stairs of the station and begins sprintin east. The streets are slick with rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights from the Brooklyn Bridge's suspension cables a reflected in the dark waters of the East River. A white rose floats beneath the bridge, pelted by the fal rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam finally reaches the great bridge. He runs up the walk Henry stands alone on the walkway beneath one of the two stone arches that rise above the bridge. The Manhattan-bo traffic rumbles by behind him. He ignores the rain. Henry stares at the giant clockface atop a building in Brooklyn. The clock reads 11:57.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Henry! Henry turns and sees Sam running toward him. We now see t Henry holds the revolver in his right hand. The headlights of passing cars flicker over both men's fa Henry smiles.  96.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Dr. Foster. I'm glad you came to watch.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (gasping for air) I didn't come to watch. I came to stop you. Henry cocks the hammer of his revolver.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (speaking rapidly) I found your waitress tonight. I found Athena. She remembers you. The mention of her name seems to make Henry distraught. H shakes his head violently.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to hurt her.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You haven't hurt anyone yet, Henry. Just put the gun down.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I've hurt people. I have. I've done something terrible.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Just put the gun down, Henry. Okay? Put the gun down. Let me help you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's the only way out. Don't you see that?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: One of the first times I met you you said you didn't know what was real anymore. Okay, well I thought I did but I was wrong. I don't know what's real, either. And if you die-

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You're real, Dr. Foster. You tried to save me. You were just a little too late. (beat) For the longest time I didn't understand what was happening to me. But now--  97.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: But you waited. Why didn't you shoot yourself as soon as you knew? You wanted me to help you. why?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Because I'm afraid. I don't know what's on the other side. (beat) Maybe that's why I can't wake up. I'm afraid to go back there.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Then don't. Don't go back.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's a dream. It's got to end sometime.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Listen. Listen to me. If you're wrong, you pull the trigger and you're dead. End of story.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'm not wrong. Sam nods but says nothing for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (very quiet) Okay. What if you're right? What if it is your dream? Look around. Look around! Henry takes his eyes off Sam and looks around. The cars r by, headlights streaming. Below the bridge the East River flows. And behind them are the towers of Manhattan. Everything shimmers in the rainfall. The skyline looks bo majestic and fragile.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The whole world is in your dream. Athena's here, I'm here, everyone. You kill yourself, you're killing all of us. (beat) Stay here. Stay with us.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I have to wake up.  98. The moment he says these words everything goes quiet. The bridge is suddenly empty, no traffic at all, nobody in si but Henry and Sam. The rain stops. The stars, normally invisible above the c now crowd the sky, brighter and more numerous than we've seen them. Then the stars begin to fall, all the stars rain from the sky, leaving burning trails in their wake, the entire sky crisscrossed with these scars. An apocalyptic howl, the most terrifying noise imaginable seems to erupt from everywhere and nowhere. The bridge shudders and sways. Henry shoves the barrel of the revolver into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Please don't. Please-- CLOSE on Henry. He pulls the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO WHITE
dialogues.text: Very bright. People in the theater should be shielding th eyes. As we fade in we see that the bright light is actually a small flashlight, shining directly into the camera.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He's still alive. The camera pulls back to show Henry lying on his back on walkway, blood streaming from his head. Sam is crouched beside him, holding one of his wrists. In his other hand, holds a small flashlight, which he shines in Henry's eyes Sam is not wearing his navy-blue cable-knit sweater, thou he was before Henry shot himself. The camera pulls back farther. This is the Brooklyn Bridg but this is not the scene we just left., A Ford Mustang h just been in a terrible collision. There is a gaping hole in the windshield on the driver's side. Flames consume the backseat. Smoke spills out the windows. The radio still plays, however: The Band's "I Sh be Released."  99. One of the Mustang's front tires has blown out. Scraps of black rubber litter the accident scene. ATHENA is kneeling next to Henry, on the opposite side of Sam, holding Henry's other hand. Henry's arms are burned and lacerated from the accident. Other cars have stopped short of the Mustang. All Manhatt bound traffic has come to a halt. From the distance, we h the blaring of horns.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: (in shock) He's okay, right? He's going to be okay? Sam leans closer to the injured man, so that his face is hovering right above Henry's. Henry's eyes are open. He appears able to see, but he's losing a tremendous amount of blood. It puddles below him the asphalt, deep red in the bridge's incandescent lights

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (to the gathering crowd) We need an ambulance! Somebody call an ambulance! He begins to unbutton his shirt. BETH LEVY gets out of a stopped car and hurries over. She wears the navy-blue cab knit SWEATER, which she now quickly shrugs out of and han to Sam.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Here, use this. Sam bundles the sweater and presses it against the deep unseen gash on Henry's head.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just called 911. They're on the way.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (to Athena) Hold this-- He has Athena hold the sweater to staunch the bleeding.  100.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: (to Henry) Stop bleeding, baby. Okay? You've got to stop bleeding now. Sam pinches Henry's nostrils and blows into his mouth to sure the airways are clear.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He's breathing. Hold that tight. Sam goes to check on the other two casualties. The first, old man, lies halfway out of one of the rear windows. Sam checks his pulse. Nothing. Sam shakes his head and walks around to the other side of car, but we PULL IN for a closer look at the old man. It's LEON. Blood leaks from his nostrils and mouth. On the other side of the car lies MRS. LETHAM, face up, e open. Blood streams down her face from a massive head wou Sam checks her pulse as well, but it's obvious she's dead Sam closes her eyelids, hurries back to Henry, and crouch beside him.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: His mom and dad? Are they okay?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: They're both gone. CLOSE ON HENRY'S EYES. We can tell that he has registered this news. For a moment the frames projected on screen slow from the 24-per-second clip and then melt away entirely. The white screen is replaced by a shot we've seen before: Henry, al on the empty bridge, walking from the burning Mustang. The vision disappears as quickly as it appeared, and we'r back at the accident scene, watching Sam trying desperate to save Henry. In the backseat of one of the stopped cars, a BABY, strap into its baby seat, HOWLS and howls. A crowd has gathered around the accident scene. From the nearest cars come the drivers and their passengers, circl around Henry. The strange thing is that we recognize all of them.  101. The Englishman and his wife. Sheriff Kennelly (not in uniform). A young woman we last saw on the subway, asking Henry about his Spanish Art class, and the businessman wh wanted him to quit smoking. Dr. Schlegel and the burly paramedics (not in uniform). A middle-aged Filipino weari Mets cap. The various waitresses and cooks we saw in the diners. Devon. Smitty. The Muslim woman in full veil. The bartender from the White Horse Tavern. A crew of blonde tourists standing together. The piano movers. The boy with the red balloon and his mother.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Mommy, is that man going to die? Lila rushes over to Sam, Athena and Henry.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: I'm a nurse.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: All right, keep tabs on his pulse. If it stops we'll have to start CPR. Lila grabs Henry's wrist and checks his pulse against her watch.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Athena) What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Henry.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Can you hear me, Henry? Henry? I'm a doctor, I'm going to help you. Can you hear me? Henry's lips have begun to pale from the loss of blood. W he speaks, his mouth barely moving, Sam and Athena bend closer to hear.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Hail. Athena looks up. No hail is falling, but the lights on th suspension cables above look like pieces of ice suspended the air.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: It's not hail, baby.  102.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: He's hallucinating.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Keep him talking. Henry's eyes are still open but he appear to be fading fa He is trying to speak and his face contorts with the effo Athena bends closer to hear him.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What did he say? The blood from Henry's head wound has seeped through the sweater and onto Athena's hand. Athena struggles to keep from hysteria. She kisses Henry the forehead. When she looks up we see that her mouth and chin are spotted with Henry's blood.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: "Forgive me."

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: It wasn't your fault, Henry. I was driving right behind you. Your front tire blew out.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: You hear that, baby? It wasn't anybody's fault. CLOSE ON HENRY'S EYES. Again, it appears that he understa the message. The words have a calming effect; his face is longer contorted.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: We need an ambulance! Sam stands up and looks out over the backed-up traffic. W PULL BACK and see that the bridge is jammed with rush-hou commuters. There is no ambulance coming. Sam crouches down again and peers into Henry's eyes. He t hold of Henry's free hand (Athena holds the other hand)

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, kid, you need to stay conscious. Come on, come on, wake up! Henry mutters something. Sam leans closer to hear.  103.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You're real, Dr. Foster. Sam has no idea what Henry's talking about.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: It's Dr. Williams, Henry. Just stay with me.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Henry, come on. Come on. I need you, baby, come on.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: I'm losing the pulse, Doctor. Sam begins CPR.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Stay, Henry, stay. Stay. Stay. Stay.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY'S FACE
dialogues.text: The camera shows what Henry sees. HENRY'S POV of the crowd of faces gathered around him. At first they are clear, each face cleanly delineated. But t begin to blur and merge together. The camera PANS UP, past the blur of faces. We see the gr Gothic arches of the bridge from this angle-- the perspec of a man lying flat on his back. We have seen this view before, in Henry's painting. The camera continues to PAN UP, past the glittering tower Manhattan, up and up into the nighttime sky. Now the screen is BLACK, but we continue to hear Athena's words.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Stay. Stay. The screen is black for ten seconds. And we think it's go to stay black, except now we notices pin-pricks of light piercing the darkness. The stars are back in the sky, but these are the usual pa New York stars, not the hallucinatory fires that scarred air with their fall.  104. PAN DOWN to the bridge. Two ambulances have arrived, as well as several police ca The PARAMEDICS (not the same ones we've seen before) load three dead bodies onto stretchers, while the POLICE OFFIC mark the scene and begin questioning people in the crowd.
